Author: money_singh#6494
Content:
Hey folks - **welcome to the most fun channel ever in our entire Starknet discord**. If you're on this server, chances are you have already played around a little bit with the Starknet and Cairo ecosystem. I'm building this channel for those of us who aren't just satisfied to write Cairo code or be told our programs are being proven using "ZK". 

**This channel is for people who actually want to dive deep into the theoretical concepts behind proof systems and enrich their understanding of what's going on under the hood.  **

Author: money_singh#6494
Content: The channel tone will def be more community learning based, and we can operate as one or more study groups depending on how many people we get.  Hoping to get started with this - https://zk-learning.org/

Author: money_singh#6494
Content: Thanks for joining folks - just going to wait for ppl to join and then set up an agenda coming Monday

Author: laurip
Content:
asked already elsewhere but no definitive answer, so let's try here.
Can Cairo1 be used for privacy, in for example a L3?

Author: closer2282
Content:
Yes I suppose it can with groth16 SNARK verifier in Cairo, which means, a STARK proof of valid verification of a SNARK can be produced
https://github.com/keep-starknet-strange/garaga/blob/main/tests/cairo_snark/groth16/sample_groth16.cairo

Author: 0xcoburn
Content:
I‚Äôm just trying to wrap my head around garaga, is it a library for building snarks that can be submitted to sharp (aka a snark proved by a stark), and using garaga can you write a snark that implements privacy in the proof, i thought the verifier had to also implement privacy but idk, i might be confused.

Not super familiar with snarks and i dont exactly know what groth16 is used for.

Author: laurip
Content: Hmm, so kinda pack a non-private proof inside another proof which does provide privacy? What's the point of using Cairo then at all, wouldn't it make more sense to drop Cairo altogether and use another ZK DSL which can be verified directly in the L3

Author: 0xcoburn
Content:
I think cairo can be very easily adapted to enable privacy amongst L3‚Äôs and L2 starknet but i dont think its a feature at the moment, maybe
@FeedTheFed | StarkWare @spapini can offer some clarity around cairo and privacy focused L3 implementations üôÇ

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
I think it's the opposite, a proof without privacy includes a zk-proof for some L3. Re why Cairo and not some other DSL, same arguments for the L2 (efficiency due to STARK friendliness). If you don't care about general computation in your L3 then it might make sense to use something else.

Also, what @Coburn | StarkTitan said, you can modify the STARK protocol a bit and obtain ZK, and do that in your L3 if you like.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: The idea with Garaga is not using SHARP directly, you use another proof system for your purposes, what SHARP will eventually see is just a proof for a block containing a tx which is a SNARK verification. If the SNARK doesn't leak information, you don't care about the properties of SHARP here (even if everything is leaked, you see the entire execution trace of the verification of the SNARK proof, and you end up with no information due to the zk property of the underlying SNARK).

Author: jackinabinet
Content: Hello and gm! Curious when users can/what upgrade will allow users to force include transactions on Polygon zkEVM in the event of a sequencer failure and withdraw in the event of a propose failure

Author: scarletssstarktitan
Content: AFAIK, Arbitrum( UseOptimistic Rollup), addresses this by allowing a user to submit transactions to the Layer 1 contract‚Äôs Delayed Inbox . These transactions are not included in the current block so they cannot be used for front-running, and if they are not processed within a 24 hour time period, they can be forced( escape hatch). For a ZK-proof  like polygon zkevm or StarkNet, there are additional challenges to implementing Forced Transactions, because Unlike Optimistic Rollups(arbitrum), ZKRollups require proofs to be submitted to the validator on Ethereum.(e.g All StarkNet state transitions inherit the security of Ethereum.)  i don't know what polygon zkevm 's plan about escape hatch, but i guess starknet plan to do it base on the decentralized sequencer ( not just forced?)?if i am wrong pls correct me @Closer | StarkTitan  if you are interested in , here is introduction  about Madara  sequencer which is new Starknet sequencer, based on substrate, (talk about escape hatch) https://twitter.com/MadaraStarknet/status/1690262971388485632

Author: closer2282
Content:
Yes i suppose you're right, and there's a post in community forum exploring Starknet escape hatch. maybe we can check it, cc @Jack
https://community.starknet.io/t/starknet-escape-hatch-research/1108

Author: c_jacksparo
Content:
A quick thought looking for feedback

Problem statement,
A chain is only as decentralized as its validators.
Using delegated proof of stake, employs economics to solve this.
The problem is that open economies naturally lead to a 10%, who are really good at capitol allocation, owning over 85% of the value.
This does not lend itself well to decentralized governance.

Solution:
Step 1 - The Chain
Imagine a POS ZKP state machine, where the validators are blind to the state changes they are validating, and blind to who sent these transactions (using relayers).
Essentially making all transactions indistinguishable one from the other. The state machine is either on and processing transactions or off.

Step 2 - Governance
Imagine a wallet that lets you choose the validators you trust. Enabling you to seamlessly interact with any protocol that has enough of your trusted validators.
Going further, what if the users could select preferences for general chain governance. As to only use chains that follow from a set of preferred rule sets they are comfortable with. 

Of course a wallet with good UX is crucial, providing users with a recommended trust setup which they can toggle. Perhaps big names in the space may have their trust setups copied with a one click ux while wallet prompts help with security.

Protocols & liquidity are incentivized towards chains with the most users. This translates a user's trust threshold into a practical vote on governance. 

Abstract summary:
A democratic republic for the digital world, this setup lets each person have a vote in governance. As for how we know what‚Äôs human and what isn‚Äôt. The onus is on the validators, protocols, and liquidity to figure out where the users are. For it is in their best interest to do so. 

Technical summary:
Stake slashing, blind validation, reputational risk, and user side custom trust thresholds.
